course.subject: ENVS
course.name: Global Climate Change
course.description: Climate change is considered the greatest threat to biodiversity and the ecosystem functions due to significant change in the measures of climate lasting for an extended period of time. This course aims to provide students with a solid foundation in physical climate system, with which to understand global warming, natural climate variations and climate models. We will also consider regional climate anomalies, unusual sequences of recent climate change, impacts of climate change in ecosystems and technologies to slow and stabilize climate change.
course.prerequisites: ENVS 2003 AND ENVS 2004

reviews.author: scientist123
reviews.comment_content: The content is useful, especially there is mathematics equation to learn, not about learning general knowledge of the global climate change and the greenhouse effect. There is physics, chemistry behind the course and therefore it is very board and meaningful.
reviews.comment_teaching: Karen and Leon are both good teachers. They elaborate scientific knowledge and maths in a very well managed well that is very clear. Although there is some difficult equations, they could elaborate fluently to students

reviews.author: YSA
reviews.title: Interesting and relevant topics, great professors. But the workload is annoying, and grading is NOT FAIR
reviews.comment_content:
Great introduction to climate change. The course is focused more on concepts, not too many advanced calculations.

Topics:

L1 - Introduction to Climate Change
L2 - Climate System and Its Components
L3 - Atmospheric General Circulations and Climate
L4 - Solar Radiation and Energy Balance
L5 - Climate Forcing and Feedback
L6 - Biogeochemistry and climate
L7 - Climate Variability
L8 - Paleoclimate and Modern Climate
L9 - Climate Model and IPCC Report
L10 - Mitigation of Climate Change

This course combines ENVS 2003 and ENVS 2004, and focuses on global warming and climate change. No other physics, chemistry, or math background is required.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Leon is the lecturer for most of the topics. He explains topics slowly and carefully, but the lectures can be a bit boring especially at 9:00 am...

Karen is awesome, as in all her other courses like Ocean Science and Ecology. But she is only here for 2 or 3 lectures in the entire semester.

All the lecture notes are very detailed and great for exam revision.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm: 35%
Final: 35%
Group presentation: 10%
Group peer review: 5%
Project report: 10%
Class participation: 5%

Midterm and final have many MCQs and a few short questions, some are just calculations or interpreting graphs/diagrams.

Midterm mean = 62
Final mean = 60
Presentation mean = 73.5
Report mean = 64

My results:

Midterm = 83
Final = 80
Presentation = 71.5
Report = 70

Final grade = B+

The final grade makes no sense. I got >1 SD above mean in the midterm and final, close to the highest score in both exams. Above mean in the report, slightly below mean in presentation. Even with 0% in class participation, it should be at least A- grade. Unless they give A-range grade to only 2 or 3 out of 40 students.

Ridiculous grade distribution. In any other course, or if I did this same course with same exam scores at any other university, I would get A- or A for sure.
reviews.comment_workload:
The midterm and final require a lot of memorization.

The project is a bit unnecessary and waste of time. There is a 10-minute presentation and 5-page report. That takes up a lot of time during the last 2-3 weeks of the semester, just for 20% of the final grade in this course.

The project should be optional for an extra bonus grade, as a lot of students are year 3 or year 4, it's too much workload with FYP, etc.

Attendance 5% is also very unnecessary, for a 9:00 am course.

reviews.author: 淺水健
reviews.comment_content:
Julian Mak teach the midterm part and Wang Yan teach final examination content
In this course you will learn:
weather, climate, some mathematics models(equations), meridional circulation, polar votex, different oceans' circulation pattern etc..
reviews.comment_teaching: Julian Mak is nice, he will set a time for you to meet with him in zoom and you can ask some questions about the lecture. Both professors will release mock question that similar with the real one for students practice. Julian Mak more funny comparing with Wang Yan.
reviews.comment_grading:
However my grading is not good. My midterm higher than mean a bit and final lower than mean near 1sd. Full attendance. Got C+

Here are the marking standard.
Mid-term 45% + final 45% + attendance 10%
Highest mark: 96.4%;
Average mark: 78.7%;
Median:  79.3%
Standard deviation: 11.2%

They said the average/median are 10% higher than ENVS 3004 in previous years, and the standard deviation remains the same
reviews.comment_workload: High, the content of the course is quite difficult and have to spend more time to understand it. During midterm and final examination in this semester they will release a PDF file including questions. Students have a week to finish the problems.
